I'm Frank Dobbin.

I'm a Professor of
Sociology at Harvard,

and I study diversity programs
in corporations and what works

and what doesn't and,
especially, what backfires.

We've known for decades that
the American workforce is
becoming more and more diverse.

What companies have
been doing for really

the last 50 years
is trying to change
what's in managers' minds.

So trying to eradicate
bias and it actually

leads them to resist trying
to promote diversity.

And if you look at the
overall trend lines,

the likelihood that Black men
and women and that Hispanic men

and women will make it
into management jobs

has barely changed at all
since the early 1980s.

What our research
shows is that a bunch

of different practices
that are related
can have positive effects.

They all have to
do with changing

career systems so they're
more open to all groups.

We find that one of the most
effective things they can do
is to create a task force.

The CEO appoints
or invites people

to be on the task
force, usually managers
from different departments.

And the group comes together
every couple of months

and looks at the data, looks
at where the problems are.

When it comes to
recruitment, that

means recruiting at historically
Black colleges, as well
as majority white colleges.

When it comes to mentoring,
it means offering everybody
in the organization a mentor.

When it comes to internal
training for management

and supervision or
even skills training,

it means having an
open system where

people can nominate themselves
for supervisory training.

When you start to open systems
up to different groups,

the opening up tends to
help all these groups.
